bestBHT.bht: The great truth here taught is that hearts superficially impressed are apt to receive the truth with readiness, and even with joy. The heat of tribulation or persecution because of the word, or the trials which their new profession brings upon them quickly dries up their relish for the truth, and withers all the hasty promise of fruit which they showed. Such disappointing issues of a faithful and awakening ministry—alas, how frequent are they!

Henry Alford: 16.] likewise, after the same analogy:—carrying on a like principle of interpretation.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The great truth here taught is that hearts superficially impressed are apt to receive the truth with readiness, and even with joy.

The heat of tribulation or persecution because of the word, or the trials which their new profession brings upon them quickly dries up their relish for the truth, and withers all the hasty promise of fruit which they showed.
Such disappointing issues of a faithful and awakening ministry—alas, how frequent are they!
Philip Schaff: Mark 4:16. Likewise, or, ‘in like manner.’ ‘After the same analogy carrying on a like principle of interpretation’ (Alford).
John Gill: Such sort of hearers of the word are signified by the stony ground, on which the seed were sown, who are constant hearers of the word, and have some understanding of it, and some sort of affection for it, and yet their hearts are not truly broken by it.
Their stony hearts are not taken away, and hearts of flesh given them.

Seem highly pleased, and greatly delighted with it, as being a well connected scheme things; and which declares things, as heaven and eternal happiness, which they, from a principle of self love, are desirous of enjoying.

bhtAttempts.bht: The great truth taught in this verse is that hearts that are superficially impressed by the word of God are often quick to receive it with joy. However, the heat of tribulation or the trials that come along with professing faith quickly dries up their initial enthusiasm, causing their interest in the truth to wither away. This is a disappointing outcome that is all too common in ministry. These types of hearers are like the stony ground on which the seed falls, taking root and showing some affection for the word, but lacking true brokenness and a transformation of heart. Although they may seem delighted with the message, their hearts remain hardened and unchanged.

Hearts superficially impressed receive the truth with readiness and joy but quickly wither amidst trials, a common outcome in ministry. These hearers resemble stony ground: they show some affection for the word but lack brokenness. Although they may seem delighted, their hearts remain hardened.

The great truth here taught is that hearts superficially impressed are apt to receive the truth with readiness, and even with joy. The heat of tribulation or persecution because of the word, or the trials which their new profession brings upon them quickly dries up their relish for the truth, and withers all the hasty promise of fruit which they showed. Such disappointing issues of a faithful and awakening ministry—alas, how frequent are they!

The hearts superficially impressed by the word of God are quick to receive it with joy, but the trials and tribulations that come along with professing faith can dry up their initial enthusiasm. Such disappointing outcomes are all too common in ministry. These types of hearers resemble the stony ground, showing some affection for the word but lacking true brokenness of heart. Despite their apparent delight in the message, their hearts remain hardened and unchanged.

Hearts that are superficially impressed easily receive the truth with joy, but the heat of trials and persecution quickly withers the promise of fruit in their lives. Disappointing outcomes in ministry are sadly common. These hearers resemble the stony ground, showing affection for the word but lacking true brokenness. Despite their apparent delight, their hearts remain hardened and unchanged.
